[[College of Europe]] |signature = Accession Treaty 2011 Helle Thorning-Schmidt signature.svg }} '''Helle Thorning-Schmidt''' ({{IPA-da|hɛlə ˈtˢoɐ̯neŋ ˈsmed̥}}; born 14 December 1966) is a former [[Denmark|Danish]] [[politician]] who was [[Prime Minister of Denmark]] from 2011 to 2015, and the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Leader of the Social Democrats]] from 2005 to 2015. She is the first woman to hold either post. Following [[Danish general election, 2015|defeat in 2015]], she announced that she would step down as both Danish Prime Minister and Social Democratic party leader. Ending her political career in April 2016, she is the chief executive of the [[NGO]] [[Save the Children]].https://www.savethechildren.net/article/former-danish-prime-minister-helle-thorning-schmidt-appointed-lead-save-children Thorning-Schmidt served as a [[Member of the European Parliament]] for [[Denmark (European Parliament constituency)|Denmark]] from 1999 to 2004 before being elected to the [[Folketing|Danish Parliament]] in 2005. She was elected to replace [[Mogens Lykketoft]] as [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Leader of the Social Democrats]] after the [[Danish parliamentary election, 2005|2005 parliamentary election]], leading her party through the [[Danish parliamentary election, 2007|2007 parliamentary election]], which was won by the centre-right alliance, and the [[Danish parliamentary election, 2011|2011 parliamentary election]], after which she was appointed [[Prime Minister of Denmark|Prime Minister]] by [[Queen Margrethe II]]. Thorning-Schmidt holds degrees in political science from the [[University of Copenhagen]] and a graduate degree from the [[College of Europe]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.dk/Folketinget/findMedlem/SHETS.aspx |title=Folketinget – Helle Thorning-Schmidt (S) |publisher=ft.dk |accessdate=17 September 2011}} ==Early life and education== Helle Thorning-Schmidt was born in [[Rødovre]] to Holger Thorning-Schmidt, a lecturer in mathematics and national economics at the [[University of Copenhagen]], and his wife Grete. Her father was [[political conservative|politically conservative]]{{cite web|url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/utenriks/artikkel.php?artid=10010163 |title=Profil: Helle Thorning-Schmidt – VG Nett om Danmark |publisher=Vg.no |date= |accessdate=16 September 2011}} and she grew up in the [[Copenhagen]] suburb of [[Ishøj]]. She attended Ishøj Gymnasium from which she graduated in 1985. Her parents divorced when she was 10 years old.{{cite web|url=http://www.vejleamtsfolkeblad.dk/artikel/196111:Navne--Helle-Thorning-har-mistet-sin-far|title= Helle Thorning har mistet sin far|work=Vejle Amts Folkeblad|date=25 January 2010 |accessdate=16 September 2011}} Thorning-Schmidt studied [[political science]] at [[University of Copenhagen]], earning a [[cand.scient.pol.]] degree in 1994. She also holds a master's degree in [[European studies]] specialising in policy and public administration from the [[College of Europe]] in [[Bruges]], [[Belgium]], where she studied from 1992 to 1993 (she is an alumna of the [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles IV]] [[College of Europe#Promotions|promotion]]).[[Dieter Mahncke]], [[Léonce Bekemans]], [[Robert Picht]], ''The College of Europe. Fifty years of service to Europe'', [[College of Europe]], Bruges, 1999. ISBN 9080498319 At the time, Denmark had a quota administered by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of one student at this prestigious institution, and Thorning-Schmidt was selected.{{cite web|author=Olav Hergel |url=http://politiken.dk/politik/ECE1394870/portraet-helle-thorning-schmidt-den-foerste-af-danmark/ |title=Portræt: Helle Thorning-Schmidt, Den Første af Danmark cc|work=Politiken|accessdate=17 September 2011}} In addition to her native [[Danish language|Danish]], she speaks fluent [[English language|English]] and [[French language|French]]. She became a [[social democracy|social democrat]] during her studies in Belgium and joined the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democratic Party]] in 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.information.dk/277877|title=Det bliver i hvert fald en moderne velfærdsdansker|work=information|accessdate=16 September 2011}} ==Early career in the European Parliament== From 1994 to 1997, Thorning-Schmidt led the secretariat of the Danish delegation of Social Democrats in the [[European Parliament]]. After her time in [[Brussels]] she worked as an international consultant with the [[Danish Confederation of Trade Unions]] until being elected [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] in [[European Parliament election, 1999 (Denmark)|1999]]. Thorning-Schmidt was elected to the [[European Parliament]] as a member of the [[Party of European Socialists]]. During the five-year term, she was a member of the [[Committee on Employment and Social Affairs|Employment and Social Committee]] and served as a substitute on the [[Committee on Constitutional Affairs|Constitutional Committee]].[http://www.europarl.europa.eu/members/archive/alphaOrder/view.do?language=EN&id=4435 "Helle Thorning-Schmidt"], ''European Parliament''. Retrieved 24 October 2011. She co-founded the Campaign for Parliament Reform (CPR).[http://fpc.org.uk/fsblob/130.pdf Nick Clegg and Michiel van Hulten, "Reforming the European Parliament"]. Retrieved 24 October 2011. ==Member of the Folketing== In the [[2005 Danish parliamentary election]] Thorning-Schmidt was elected to the [[Folketing]]. ===Leader of the Social Democrats=== [[Image:Helle Thorning-Schmidt, 2008.jpg|thumb|upright|Thorning-Schmidt in 2008, as leader of the opposition]] After the defeat in the [[2005 Danish parliamentary election|2005 election]], in which the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]] lost five seats and failed to regain the majority it had lost in the [[2001 Danish parliamentary election|2001 election]], former [[Finance Minister of Denmark|Minister of Finance]] and party leader [[Mogens Lykketoft]] resigned his post, taking responsibility for the poor election results. In his speech of resignation on election night, 8 February 2005, he called for a leadership election in order to determine who should lead the party into the next election.[http://www.dansketaler.dk/tale.lasso?tekst_id=349 "Tale efter Folketingsvalget 2005"], ''Danske taler''. {{Da icon}}. Retrieved 24 October 2011. Thorning-Schmidt campaigned for the party leadership as a moderate candidate and was elected by the party members on 12 April 2005, ahead of the other candidate, [[Frank Jensen]]. She led the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]] in the 2007 election, in which her party suffered modest losses and was forced into a third term in opposition. The party was also unable to regain its position as the largest party in the [[Folketing]].[http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_historie/Danmark_efter_1945/Helle_Thorning-Schmidt "Helle Thorning-Schmidt"], ''Den Store Danske''. {{Da icon}}. Retrieved 24 October 2011. She was against holding a referendum on the [[Treaty of Lisbon|European Reform Treaty]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7060654.stm Denmark announces snap elections], [[BBC News]] 24 October 2007 During her [[2007 Danish parliamentary election|2007 campaign]] she promised to relax restrictions on asylum seekers and immigrants.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7087474.stm Danes in poll tussle over migrants], BBC News 13 November 2007 She also opposed tax cuts announced by [[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]], instead stating she would like to see more funding for welfare. The party also campaigned on a platform of combating increased inequalities in society, and fighting global warming by supplying 45% of Denmark's energy from renewable sources by 2025.[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2007/nov/09/gwladysfouche1 Denmark: A political guide], [[The Guardian]] 9 November 2007 Although her party again lost two seats in the 2007 election reducing the total to 45 seats, her leadership was not questioned by her party.Munk, Andreas. [http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Temaer/2011/Valg/2011/09/27/160041.htm "Helle Thorning – en socialt anlagt slider"], ''DR'', 2 October 2011. {{Da icon}}. Retrieved 24 October 2011. In June 2008, according to a [[Gallup poll|Gallup]] poll, the opposition centre-left was at 49.8% compared to 49.6% for the centre-right. This would leave the centre-left with 88 seats, two short of a majority, discounting the [[Faroe Island]] and [[Greenland]] seats.[http://www.bt.dk/politik/oppositionen-gaar-paa-ferie-med-flertal Oppositionen går på ferie med flertal "Oppositionen gaar på ferie med flertal"], ''Berlingske'', 28 June 2008, {{Da icon}}. Retrieved 24 October 2011. Since late 2009 the opposition enjoyed large majorities in the polls, and according to polls carried out in January 2011 the opposition led the governing coalition under [[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]] by 5–7 points and the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]] led [[Liberal Party (Denmark)|Venstre]] by 7–10 points which would make the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]] the largest party by far in the [[Folketing]].{{cite web|url=http://borsen.dk/nyheder/politik/artikel/1/199773/vaelgerne_straffer_pia_kjaersgaard.html |title=Vælgerne straffer Pia Kjærsgaard |publisher=Borsen.dk |date=21 January 2011 |accessdate=16 September 2011}} [[File:Thorning-Schmidt.jpg|thumb|upright|Helle Thorning-Schmidt, 2010.]] Both [[Margrethe Vestager]] ([[Danish Social Liberal Party|Social Liberal Party]]) and [[Villy Søvndal]] ([[Socialist People's Party (Denmark)|Socialist People's Party]]) have pledged their support to Thorning-Schmidt after a potential election victory.{{cite web|url=http://borsen.dk/nyheder/politik/artikel/1/143035/vestager_peger_paa_helle_thorning.html |title=Vestager peger på Helle Thorning |publisher=Borsen.dk |date=20 October 2008 |accessdate=16 September 2011}} After the [[2007 Danish parliamentary election|last election]] Helle Thorning-Schmidt started working towards forming a [[centre-left]] government coalition consisting of the [[Socialist People's Party (Denmark)|Socialist People's Party]] and the [[Danish Social Liberal Party|Social Liberal Party]] with parliamentary support from the small [[Red-Green Alliance (Denmark)|Red-Green Alliance]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.dk/politik/roed-dominans |title=Rød dominans – Politik |publisher=BT.dk |date= |accessdate=16 September 2011 |language= da}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Politik/2010/12/02/232622.htm |title=Greens: Markant rødt flertal – dr.dk/Nyheder/Politik |publisher=Dr.dk |date= |accessdate=16 September 2011}} As the leader of the largest opposition party in Denmark, she was described by the media as the leader of the Danish opposition.{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/191250/danish-opposition-wins-vote-delivering.html |title=Danish opposition wins vote, delivering first woman PM | Deccan Herald |publisher=Deccanherald.com |date=16 September 2011}} ===Appointment as Prime Minister=== {{See also|Danish parliamentary election, 2011}} In the [[Danish parliamentary election, 2011|2011 parliamentary election]], she was re-elected to parliament. Although the ruling [[Venstre (Denmark)|Liberal Party]] became the largest party and gained a seat and the Social Democrats lost a seat, the opposition parties combined obtained more seats than the government coalition. Her four-party bloc gained a majority of 89 seats in the 179-seat parliament against 86 for the sitting Prime Minister and his center-right parliamentary supporters. Prime Minister [[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]] formally tendered his resignation to Queen Margrethe on 16 September 2011. Rasmussen's cabinet remained in office as a [[caretaker government]]{{cite web|author=Marie Hjortdal |url=http://politiken.dk/politik/ECE1394823/loekke-gaar-af---nu-begynder-spillet-om-magten/ |title=Løkke går af – nu begynder spillet om magten |language=da |publisher=Politiken.dk |date= |accessdate=16 September 2011}} until 3 October, when Helle Thorning-Schmidt was appointed Prime Minister by the Queen following negotiations with the other opposition parties. ==Prime Minister of Denmark== [[File:Regeringen Helle Thorning-Schmidt 036.jpg|thumb|The first Cabinet presented at [[Amalienborg]]]] ===First Cabinet=== {{Main|Cabinet of Helle Thorning-Schmidt I}} Helle Thorning-Schmidt officially began her first term as Prime Minister on 3 October 2011, after having presented her cabinet to the Queen and having received her official appointment.[http://www.ambvilnius.um.dk/en/menu/Aboutus/News/APPOINTMENTOFNEWGOVERNMENTINDENMARK.htm "Appointment of New Government in Denmark"], ''Embassy of Denmark Lithuania''. Retrieved 24 October 2011. Thorning-Schmidt has pursued a [[centrist]] compromise agenda, building several reforms with support from both sides of the Folketing. This has caused friction with the supporting Red-Green Alliance, which has been kept outside of influence.{{cite news |title=Government on track but off message |first=Ray |last=Weaver |url=http://www.cphpost.dk/news/politics/government-track-message |newspaper=[[The Copenhagen Post]] |date=18 May 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2012}} Thorning-Schmidt presided over the successful conclusion of [[NATO]]'s [[Operation Unified Protector|strike missions]] in [[Libya]], to which Denmark was a contributor, less than three weeks after taking office.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/nato-to-decide-friday-to-end-the-aerial-campaign-over-libya-diplomats-say/2011/10/20/gIQAlpk10L_story.html|agency=The Washington Post|title=NATO: to decide Friday to end the aerial campaign over Libya, diplomats say|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=21 October 2011}} During the first year in office her government rolled back anti-immigration legislation enacted by the previous government,{{cite news |title=A Blow to Europe’s Far-Right: Denmark Reshapes Its Immigration Policies |first=William Lee |last=Adams |url=http://world.time.com/2011/10/06/a-slap-to-europes-far-right-denmark-reshapes-its-immigration-policies |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher=TimeWorld |date=6 October 2011 |accessdate=20 September 2012}}/ and passed a tax-reform with support from the liberal-conservative opposition.{{cite news |title=Government defends tax deal with opposition |first=Peter |last=Stanners |url=http://www.cphpost.dk/news/politics/government-defends-tax-deal-opposition |newspaper=[[The Copenhagen Post]] |date=25 June 2012 |accessdate=20 September 2012}} The tax reform raised the top tax threshold, effectively lowering tax rates for high income earners.{{cite news |title=PM supports call to raise top tax threshold |agency=PS |url=http://www.cphpost.dk/news/politics/pm-supports-call-raise-top-tax-threshold |newspaper=[[The Copenhagen Post]] |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2012}} The aim of the tax reform has been to increase labour output to fend off a projected shortage within the next decades. The stated goal is to entice Danes to work more in order to compensate for the decreasing workforce, by lowering tax on wages and gradually lowering welfare payments to those outside of the labour market to increase the economic benefit of working relative to receiving welfare.{{cite news |title=Helle Thorning-Schmidt: Danes must work more |first=Marie |last= Preisler |url=http://www.nordiclabourjournal.org/nyheter/news-2011-1/article.2011-10-06.6407706507 |work=Nordic Labour Journal |publisher=[[Work Research Institute]] |date=6 October 2011 |accessdate=22 September 2012}} On 9 August and 12 December 2013, amid tensions between coalition partners, Thorning-Schmidt made [[cabinet reshuffle]]s. ===Second Cabinet=== {{Main|Cabinet of Helle Thorning-Schmidt II}} [[File:The Prime Ministers of the Nordic Council in October 2014 - 02.jpg|thumb|Thorning-Schmidt with heads of government from the [[Nordic countries]]]] On 30 January 2014, the Socialist People's Party announced their departure from Thorning-Schmidt's government due to a conflict over the proposed sale of [[DONG Energy]] shares to [[Goldman Sachs]]. Before departure, they also announced they will support Thorning-Schmidt although not being a part of her government.{{cite web|title=SF leaves government, Vilhelmsen steps down|url=http://cphpost.dk/news/sf-leaves-government-vilhelmsen-steps-down.8476.html|publisher=[[The Copenhagen Post]]|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=30 January 2014}} Thorning-Schmidt led her party into the [[Danish general election, 2015|2015 general election]] in which her party increased its share of votes and seats, but the left bloc was defeated by the right bloc. She announced her resignation as [[Prime Minister of Denmark]] and as leader of the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]] after the election results became clear. ==Electoral history== Thorning has been leader of the Social Democrats through seven electoral campaigns.{{cite web|url=http://www.statistikbanken.dk/valgk3/|title=Population and Elections|publisher=StatBank Denmark|date= |accessdate=September 27, 2014}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |- ! Year !! Type !! Votes !! % !! Change in % !! Seats !! Change in Seats |- | [[Danish local elections, 2005|2005]] || Local || 986,829 || 34.3 || +1.5 || 900 || n/a |- | [[Danish general election, 2007|2007]] || General || 881,037 || 25.5 || −0.3 || 45 || −2 |- | [[European Parliament election, 2009 (Denmark)|2009]] || European || 503,439 || 21.5 || −11.1 || 4 || −1 |- | [[Danish local elections, 2009|2009]] || Local|| 853,221 || 30.6 || −4.9 || 801 || −99 |- | [[Danish general election, 2011|2011]] || General || 879,615 || 24,8 || −0.7 || 44 || −1 |- | [[Danish local elections, 2013|2013]] || Local || 919,574 || 29.5 || −0.9 || 773 || −28 |- | [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Denmark)|2014]] || European || 435,245 || 19.1 || −2.4 || 3 || −1 |- | [[Danish general election, 2015|2015]] || General || 925,635 || 26.3 || +1.5 || 47 || +3 |} ==Personal life== She married [[Stephen Kinnock]] (who became a British MP in 2015) in 1996, so becoming the daughter-in-law of [[Neil Kinnock]], former leader of the British [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and European Commissioner, and [[Glenys Kinnock, Baroness Kinnock of Holyhead|Glenys Kinnock]], former British Minister for Europe. She met her husband while they were both attending the [[College of Europe]]. They have two daughters, Johanna and Camilla. Helle lives in [[Copenhagen]] with their children, while her husband partly resided in [[Davos]], [[Switzerland]], where he worked as a director for the [[World Economic Forum]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-14944749 |title=BBC News – Profile: Danish PM-elect Helle Thorning-Schmidt |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=3 August 2010 |accessdate=17 September 2011}} In 2014 he worked for [[London]]-based [[Xyntéo]] as managing director for the "Global Leadership and Technology Exchange",{{Cite web | title = Stephen Kinnock | url = http://www.xynteo.com/about/people/stephen-kinnock }} but he was elected [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Aberavon (UK Parliament constituency)|Aberavon]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015]]. Having lost the Danish general election of 2015, she stepped down as Prime Minister and as leader of the Social Democratic Party. It was announced that Thorning-Schmidt would become her party's member of the Presidium of the Folketing and she currently serves as the Presidium's 1st Vice-President. On 4 September 2015, Prime Minister [[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]] announced that the Danish government has nominated Thorning-Schmidt as Denmark’s official candidate to the position as new [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]].{{cite web|url=http://um.dk/en/news/newsdisplaypage/?newsID=36057D33-4165-448E-97FA-2CB3EF498769 |title=Denmark nominates Mrs. Helle Thorning-Schmidt to the position as new UN High Commissioner for Refugees |publisher=http://um.dk/ |accessdate=7 September 2015}} ===Religious beliefs=== Although Thorning-Schmidt has been [[Lutheranism#Baptism|baptized]], she is not [[Confirmation (Lutheran Church)|confirmed]]. She occasionally goes to church and does not believe in [[Eternal life (Christianity)|eternal life]], [[salvation]], [[heaven]], or [[hell]].{{cite web |url=http://qz.com/334402/these-are-the-religious-beliefs-of-europes-leaders-including-the-atheists/ |title=These are the religious beliefs of Europe’s leaders—including the atheists |author=Kabir Chibber, Jason Karaian |date=28 January 2015 |website=Quartz |accessdate=31 January 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.kristeligt-dagblad.dk/kirke-tro/helle-thorning-schmidt-om-tro-og-liv-efter-døden |title=Helle Thorning-Schmidt om tro og liv efter døden |last=Hansen |first=Mette Skov |date=14 September 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2015 |language=Danish |trans-title=Helle Thorning-Schmidt on faith and life after death}} ===Tax affairs=== The [[SKAT (tax agency)|Danish tax authorities (SKAT)]] investigated reports that Thorning-Schmidt's husband, Stephen Kinnock, was guilty of [[tax evasion]]. Kinnock had declared that he was not a resident of Denmark and thus not subject to Danish taxes, while at the same time Thorning-Schmidt had declared, in an application for dispensation for Kinnock to own property in Denmark, that he resided in Denmark "every weekend of the year from Friday through to Monday".[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-10856352 Danish politics rocked over Kinnock tax status], BBC News 3 August 2010 Thorning-Schmidt attributed the discrepancy to a "big and sloppy error". On 16 September 2010, Danish tax authorities acquitted the couple and the charges of tax evasion were dropped.[http://politiken.dk/politik/ECE1061397/revisor-skat-frikender-thorning-i-skattesag/ Revisor: Skat frikender Thorning i skattesag], [[Politiken]] 16 September 2010 {{da icon}} A week before the 15 September 2011 elections to the Danish Parliament, the 2010 decision from SKAT (the taxation department) surfaced in the Danish tabloid ''[[B.T. (tabloid)|B.T.]]'' The case had been leaked to the newspaper several months previously. It turned out that from 2000 to 2008 Thorning-Schmidt had made use of tax deductions applicable to her husband, even though he was not subject to Danish taxes and had no income in Denmark. The mistake was corrected by SKAT for the three years from 2006 to 2008, and Thorning-Schmidt paid the amount she had saved due to the error. She was however not required to pay the amounts saved for the six years from 2000 to 2005, because of the statutory time limit for liability in such cases.[http://www.bt.dk/politik/thorning-fik-uberettiget-fradrag-i-seks-aar/ Thorning fik uberettiget fradrag i seks år], [[B.T. (tabloid)|B.T.]] 17 September 2011 In November 2011 the daily ''[[Politiken]]'' disclosed that ''[[Tax Ministry of Denmark|Tax Ministry]]'' deputy chief Peter Loft had attended several meetings attending to the Thorning-Schmidt case and had tried to insert comments into the final resolution text. This would be unlawful under Danish law as the Tax Ministry may not interfere with the decisions taken in individual tax cases.[http://politiken.dk/politik/ECE1447272/ministers-hoejre-haand-skrev-afsnit-i-thorning-sag/ Ministers højre hånd skrev afsnit i Thorning-sag], [[Politiken]] 11 November 2011 This set off a flurry of speculation in the press, as to whether there had been any political pressure from the then government to pursue a stricter course in the tax case. Tax Minister in the new government Thor Möger Pedersen subsequently asked Peter Loft and the director of the revenue service's Copenhagen branch, Erling Andersen, to give a report on the happenings. On 2 December, Pedersen disclosed that he had found such big discrepancies in the two reports that he would set up a commission of inquiry to determine the actual course of events.[http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Politik/2011/12/02/093947.htm/ Kommission skal kulegrave skattesag], [[Danmarks Radio|DR]] 2 December 2011 Further controversy erupted when two days later the tabloid daily, ''[[Ekstra Bladet]]'', reported that they had also been offered the confidential information that was made public during the election campaign. The source of the leak was determined to be Peter Arnfeldt, spin doctor for then Minister for Taxation [[Troels Lund Poulsen]].[http://politiken.dk/politik/ECE1469714/avis-troels-lunds-spindoktor-ville-laekke-thornings-skattepapirer/ Avis: Troels Lunds spindoktor ville lække Thornings skattepapirer], [[Politiken]] 4 December 2011 {{da icon}} This led to intense media speculation that the former government, and specifically Troels Lund Poulsen, were engaged in leaking confidential tax information and trying to pressure the revenue service into changing its decision in the case, in an active attempt to discredit the opposition leader in the then imminent election. This would constitute a hitherto unseen level of abuse of power in Danish political life. The commission of inquiry that had already been announced two days previously, was broadly supported by the Danish Parliament to also look into whether the former government was involved in, or knew of, the leak.[http://politiken.dk/politik/ECE1470465/undersoegelseskommissionen-ventes-klar-hurtigt/ Undersøgelseskommissionen ventes klar hurtigt], [[Politiken]] 5 December 2011 On the same day Troels Lund Poulsen announced he would be taking an indefinite leave of absence from the Danish Parliament. Peter Arnfeldt has been reported to the police by the Ministry for Taxation. In March 2012 Peter Loft was suspended from his post as deputy chief, for the duration of the two-year investigation period.[http://politiken.dk/politik/ECE1576103/skatteminister-suspenderer-sin-departementschef/ Skatteminister fritager sin departementschef fra tjeneste], Politiken. 21 March 2012 {{da icon}} ===Selfie controversy=== In December 2013, Thorning-Schmidt, British Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] and US President [[Barack Obama]] faced criticism on social media that they had behaved inappropriately after posing for a "[[selfie]]" taken with Thorning-Schmidt's mobile phone during [[Death and state funeral of Nelson Mandela|the memorial service]] for the former South African President [[Nelson Mandela]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2013/1210/492048-barack-obama-david-cameron-nelson-mandela/ |title=Obama and Cameron criticised for memorial 'selfie'|work= RTÉ News |publisher=RTÉ |date=10 December 2013 |accessdate=13 December 2013}} Defending her actions, Thorning-Schmidt said, "There were lots of pictures taken that day, and I just thought it was a bit fun. Maybe it also shows that when we meet heads of state and government, we too are just people who have fun."{{cite news|last=Dominiczak|first=Peter|title=Nelson Mandela: Helle Thorning-Schmidt defends David Cameron 'selfie'|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/nelson-mandela/10511954/Nelson-Mandela-Helle-Thorning-Schmidt-defends-David-Cameron-selfie.html|accessdate=13 December 2013|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=12 December 2013}} Cameron said he was being polite when Thorning-Schmidt asked him to take part in the picture. On a previous occasion, Thorning-Schmidt had stopped her car to ask for a picture with the actress [[Sarah Jessica Parker]] after spotting her signing autographs in Oslo.{{cite news|last=Mason|first=Rowena|last2= Harding|first2= Luke|title=David Cameron and Danish PM brush off criticism of Mandela memorial selfie|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/dec/11/david-cameron-danish-pm-mandela-memorial-selfie|accessdate=13 December 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 December 2013}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons}} {{Wikinews|Denmark elects new centre-left coalition and prime minister}} *[http://stm.dk/_a_2761.html Prime Minister's website] {{en icon}} *{{Dmoz|World/Dansk/Samfund/Politik/Partier/Socialdemokraterne/Politikere/}} {{da icon}} {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mogens Lykketoft]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Leader of the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Social Democrats]]|years=2005–2015}} {{s-aft|after=[[Mette Frederiksen]]}} |- {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Prime Minister of Denmark]]|years=2011–2015}} {{s-aft|after=[[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]]}} |- {{s-aca}} {{s-bef|before=[[Giorgio Napolitano]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Opening ceremony|Invocation]] Speaker of the [[College of Europe]]|years=2012}} {{s-aft|after=[[Íñigo Méndez de Vigo]]}} {{S-ach}} {{succession box |before = {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Connie Hedegaard]] |title = European of the Year

She co-led the [[Orange Revolution]][[#BBCprofile|BBC News profile]] and was the first woman appointed [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]],{{cite news|author=Mark MacKinnon|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/peace-deal-that-frees-yulia-tymoshenko-a-harsh-blow-to-ukraines-president/article17052169/|title=Peace deal that frees Yulia Tymoshenko a harsh blow to Ukraine’s President|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=21 February 2014|accessdate=7 November 2015}} serving from 24 January to 8 September 2005, and again from 18 December 2007 to 4 March 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100311220422/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/60896/|archivedate=2010-03-11|title=Ukraine parliament votes out Tymoshenko's government|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=3 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60998/|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100307140238/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/60998/|archivedate=2010-03-07|title=Press secretary: Tymoshenko vacates premier's post|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=4 March 2010}} Tymoshenko is the leader of the [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"]] political party that has 19 seats in parliament{{cite news|url=http://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-politics/1726373-poroshenko_bloc_to_have_greatest_number_of_seats_in_parliament_327072.html |title=Poroshenko Bloc to have greatest number of seats in parliament |publisher=[[Ukrinform]] |date=8 November 2014 |accessdate=6 November 2015 }}

In the [[2012 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] the party had received the second most votes, winning 101 of parliament's 450 seats.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-20204527|title=Ukraine election:Opposition rally against 'rigged' poll|work=BBC News|date=5 November 2012|accessdate=7 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-party-of-regions-gets-185-seats-in-ukrainian-parliament-batkivschyna-101-315948.html|title=CEC: Party of Regions gets 185 seats in Ukrainian parliament, Batkivschyna 101|work=Kyiv Post|date=12 November 2012|accessdate=7 November 2015}} In the [[2014 Ukrainian presidential election]] Tymoshenko received 12.81% of the vote, coming in second place after [[Petro Poroshenko]] who won the election with 54.7%.{{cite web|url=http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20140529212731/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |archivedate=2014-05-29 |title=Poroshenko wins presidential election with 54.7% of vote – CEC |publisher=[[Radio Ukraine International]] |date=29 May 2014 }}

In the first round she had also finished second.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/update-official-result-of-first-round-of-president.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20141208141901/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/update-official-result-of-first-round-of-president.html|archivedate=2014-12-08|title=Update: Official result of first round of presidential election – Yanukovych wins 35.32%, Tymoshenko 25.05%|work=Kyiv Post|date=25 January 2010}} After the 2010 presidential election, a number of [[Criminal cases against Yulia Tymoshenko since 2010|criminal cases]] were brought against her.
